## Introduction
The Animals_Idaho_Mountain_Goat, scientifically known as Oreamnos americanus, is a species of hoofed mammal native to North America. It is particularly found in the mountainous regions of Idaho. These goats are known for their impressive climbing abilities and distinctive appearance.

## Physical Characteristics
The Animals_Idaho_Mountain_Goat is a medium-sized ungulate with a stocky build. They have a shoulder height of about 3 to 3.5 feet (0.9 to 1.1 meters) and can weigh between 100 to 300 pounds (45 to 136 kilograms). Both males and females possess short, sharp, and slightly backward-curving horns.

Their fur is dense and consists of two layers: a coarse outer layer and a soft, insulating underlayer. The color of their fur can vary from white to light tan, providing excellent camouflage in their alpine habitat. Their hooves are specially adapted for climbing steep and rocky terrain, with rough pads and sharp dewclaws for added grip.

## Habitat and Distribution
Animals_Idaho_Mountain_Goats are primarily found in the mountainous regions of Idaho, particularly in the central and northern parts of the state. They inhabit rugged terrain, including alpine meadows, cliffs, and rocky slopes. These goats are well-adapted to high elevations and are often seen in areas above the tree line.

Their distribution extends beyond Idaho, with populations also found in other western states of the United States and parts of Canada. They have a preference for habitats with ample forage and areas that provide escape from predators.

## Behavior and Lifestyle
Animals_Idaho_Mountain_Goats are highly agile climbers and spend a significant amount of time on steep slopes and cliffs. They are well-suited for their mountainous environment, with excellent balance and coordination. These goats are known for their ability to navigate narrow ledges and vertical rock faces.

They are primarily diurnal, being most active during the day. During the summer months, they may move to higher elevations to access cooler temperatures and better forage. Animals_Idaho_Mountain_Goats are social animals and live in small groups called bands. These bands consist of adult females and their young, while adult males tend to be solitary or form small bachelor groups.

## Diet
Animals_Idaho_Mountain_Goats are herbivores, primarily feeding on a variety of alpine vegetation. Their diet includes grasses, herbs, shrubs, and lichens. They are well-adapted to foraging on steep slopes and can reach vegetation that is inaccessible to other herbivores.

To obtain their food, these goats use their specialized hooves and agile climbing skills to navigate rocky terrain. They are capable of balancing on narrow ledges and reaching out to grab vegetation with their prehensile lips.

## Reproduction and Lifecycle
Breeding in Animals_Idaho_Mountain_Goats typically occurs during late fall or early winter. The males, known as billies, engage in physical contests to establish dominance and gain access to females. Once a dominant male has secured a mate, they will form a temporary bond that lasts until the female gives birth.

After a gestation period of around six months, a single kid is born in the spring. The young, known as kids, are precocial and are able to stand and walk shortly after birth. They are nursed by their mother and gradually introduced to solid food as they grow. Kids stay with their mothers for about a year before becoming independent.

The Animals_Idaho_Mountain_Goat is not currently considered endangered or threatened. However, localized populations may face threats from habitat loss, climate change, and hunting.
